descendants.content:
🧵 2/3

One of the researchers, Philippe Ciais, offered a summary of their findings, using slightly less scientific language that is perhaps easier for laypersons to understand.

Here is part of what he wrote…
_________________________________

Even if 2023 was a transition from a La Niña (good for carbon sinks) to a moderate El Niño, we see a sudden drop of the land carbon sink from extreme warming and Amazon mega-drought. In fact, the northern land sink appears to have declined by 50% since 2015 from droughts, while the tropics were a sink during the recent cool and wet La Niña from 2020 to mid 2023 and turned to a source in 2023 with a modest El Niño.

The decline of the northern sink was masked by good conditions in the tropics absorbing CO2, but in the coming years if this decline continues, we may see a rapid acceleration of CO2 and global warming which was unforeseen in future climate models projections.
_________________________________

LINK TO CIAIS’ COMMENTS ➡️ https://x.com/ciais_philippe/status/1813909589437428088

card.title: Philippe.ciais (@ciais_philippe) on X
card.description: ✅  In fact, the northern land sink appears to have declined by 50% since 2015 from droughts while the tropics recovered from 2015 El Niño, were a sink during the recent cool and wet La Niña from 2020 to mid 2023 and turned to a source in 2023 with a modest El Niño

descendants.content:
🧵 3/3

And finally, here is a brief recap of what I think it all means:

Until recently, the huge amount of CO2 absorbed by the oceans, by soils, and by plants have prevented massive rapid global heating. But those systems are changing. For the first time, 2023 showed that land sinks are not absorbing nearly as much CO2.

As the world continues getting warmer, carbon sinks will absorb less CO2, which means more CO2 emissions are ending up in the atmosphere. This may vary from year to year with ENSO (La Niña and El Niño cycles), but the overall picture is way out of line with standard predictions for future climate change.

In other words, it’s even worse than we thought.

That's assuming, of course, that the conclusions of this paper are correct. Maybe we'll get lucky and find out they're wrong.

descendants.content:
@arrrg @breadandcircuses Another thing that this shows is even if we manage to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere in quantity, *we can't use that to continue business as usual*.

We'll need it all to return atmospheric CO2 to a safe level.

Or, since we're clearly getting close to a number of tipping points, merely to offset feedbacks. 😐

account.note: Former and hopefully future climate and poverty activist. Covid cautious. Autistic grey-ace/wtf-ro geek, software developer. Interested in green transition, green tech, activism, intersectionality, etc. I try to boost other marginalised voices while recognising my own privilege. Yorkshire (UK), Remainer. Climate hawk on the pro-tech end: We need *appropriate* technology. Recently re-created this account after leaving for a while during an anxious period of unemployment.

descendants.content:
@matthewtoad43 @arrrg @breadandcircuses
And the removal must happen now, while we still emit.
Because once we stop emitting and only do removal, and hence, lower CO2 concentration in the atmosphere, it triggers yet another climate change that puts the system elements into new stress. And it also makes CO2 removal harder due to "outgassing" from both, ocean and land carbon sink. For every 1ppm, removal of 1.5ppm are required.
But I think, outgassing from the land carbon sink during CO2 removal is not a passive, gentle process like it sounds. I see outgassing as a euphemism for a stress reaction.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses Knowing and having published with Philippe, and especially since he's second on this, the results should largely hold.

Historically, scientists have been too conservative in many of these estimates (as shown here in part). I don't think this will be wholly refuted, unless substantial errors are found in the pre-print that is, given that bottom-up and top-down approaches are in agreement.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses What we're really looking at here is cascading system failure.

Because A goes wrong, B goes wrong, causing C to go wrong and so on.

And with every item which goes wrong, everything else becomes more fragile.

Really wish this wasn't happening to a system I need for continued survival.

descendants.content:
@breadandcircuses This shouldn’t be a surprise - 2023 was 3x worse than the previous record for forest fires in Canada — and I’m not a scientist, but as far as I know, trees can’t sequester CO2 when they’re on fire.

To give you a better perspective, the forest fires in Greece made the news several times in 2023…. But Canada’s fires consumed an area equal to every square inch of the country of Greece…. And 25,000 square kilometres MORE.

card.title: One of Earth's major carbon sinks collapsed in 2023
card.description: Forests and other land ecosystems emitted almost as much carbon dioxide as they absorbed in 2023 – if this persists it will be much harder to restrict global warming to agreed targets
